Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: By taking this course, I was able to practice speaking French and to improve my writing ability in this language.

This course will expose you to a great depth of vocabulary that pertains to contemporary issues and ideas in France. Through meeting three times a week, your spoken French will become more automatic and fluent. The readings are all well-written and interesting, so you will learn a lot about current French culture, as it is seen by the French.

I learned about the contemporary social issues in France, as well as its historical influences on modern society. The course provides a well-balanced analysis of the pros and cons of French society and stimulates you to have a critical evaluation.
I practiced speaking French.
I learned how to express myself much more fluently in French while also picking up knowledge about contemporary French culture through a variety of media.
I gained French proficiency and cultural knowledge

As the first French class I've taken for over a year, this course has really helped me get back into the language. I definitely improved my oral fluency, and seeing as we also did a fair bit of reading, I also improved my reading comprehension and writing skills.
I learned so much about the nuance of French society and I also think my speaking and vocabulary improved.

This class offers advanced speaking skills in French. The vehicle chosen, French history, politics, and economics, plus an introduction to the francophone  countries couldn't be more suitable. It gives the maximum vocabulary and greatly improves one's grammar and spoken expression. 

By the end of the class, speaking is much better, and the vocabulary much more robust.

It is an excellent course, very-well organized and led by Professor Pinzka. The main strength is the structure of the class-you get to practice your French in a fairly casual setting by discussing various topics related to contemporary France. I can't really think of any weaknesses.

The main strength of this class was the subject matters addressed. Each class was interesting, and most of the topics presented students to many viewpoints which encouraged debate and discussion in class. At times, the readings seemed a little heavy given that we didn't address many of them in class.
I loved that we actually spoke French here. Good! But, there is TOO much reading. I did not do half of it because it was simply impossible to keep up with.

The course facilitated group discussions based on readings and films, and explored a variety of angles of French culture. Partner presentations increased speaking confidence. I wouldve liked to have developed my writing skills more by writing a paper for the course. The tests were also a little too focused on memorizing vocabulary.
More student involvement and less talking from instructor

Strengths: reasonable workload, interesting topics, wonderful professor

Weaknesses: not really any

I think the course is the best of the whole French Dpt. because you learn so much but also arent bombarded with busy work. I do think the oral exams, for which we werent given a whole lot of tips or strategies, are worth too much of the grade.

I would definitely recommend this course to any Yale student interested in improving their French. It is an excellent, well-organized course, the material you cover is really interesting and Professor Pinzka is an amazing teacher.
If you would like to improve your spoken French and acquire new, useful vocabulary, I would definitely recommend this class.
Yes! A good course to learn about French society and comparing French culture to your own culture. It is also a comprehensive course to develop your French skills.
Yes, if you intend to work hard to improve your French.
I would highly recommend this course to another student at L5 level who is looking to learn more about French culture and improve their conversation skills.
Yes to those who want to work on oral French

Yes! This is a wonderful class. Don't be afraid of how conversation-focused it is - I personally don't like speaking up in class, and this class was very comfortable for me. You'll learn a lot about French, and Madame Pinzka really cares about how you're doing.
Yes! I already have. Such a good way to keep up your French and learn a lot (without major stress!).
Yes. If you want to improve your spoken french, definitely take this class.
